p:
To determine frog body temperatures at CT max, we later exposed four haphazardly selected L. spenceri of average sizes to the same program of gradually increasing temperature in the same chamber, following Itraconazole treatment. For each frog, we recorded body temperature at 25 °C, 30 °C, 35 °C, and 40 °C ambient temperature. We measured body temperature with a non-contact infrared thermometer (OS425-LS, Omega Engineering Ltd, Irlam, Manchester, UK; emissivity 0.95)
63 . We then modeled the relationship between ambient and body temperatures using linear regression and used this analysis to convert ambient CT max temperatures to body temperatures for all experimental frogs (y = 0.7985x + 4.0675; R 2 = 0.9886; 95% confidence interval for slope = 0.751, 0.846; 95% confidence interval for intercept = 2.503, 5.632).
